metadata.title: Journal Pre-proofs Perspective The Elements of Data Sharing

body_text.text: 62 Making data shared for the public involves a series of activities that span the entire life cycle of data 63 flow and that embody all relevant parties in terms of policies for data sharing and release (particularly 64 for data from public-funded research), standards for data description and exchange, as well as 65 databases for data management and access. All these relevant entities and processes together form a 66 data-sharing ecosystem, in which data sharing is initiated by data providers and implemented in 67 databases that play important roles in data management and provide data access for the public.
body_text.section: Data sharing demands a data ecosystem

body_text.text: 68 Therefore, elements of data sharing should cover two major camps, one for data providers (including 69 not only raw data generators, but also databases that provide data annotations and relationships (Figure 1) . Promptness is crucially important during outbreaks since "speed is everything"
body_text.section: Data sharing demands a data ecosystem

body_text.text: . It is consistent well with the Bermuda Principles, advocating rapid public release of genome 77 sequence data within 24 hours after generation and without restrictions on use proposed by the 78 International Human Genome Sequencing Consortium in 1996. Given the unexpected emergency 79 circumstances, sharing data in a timely manner is beneficial immediately for worldwide researchers 80 and long-term for the global human society. Certainly, in this particular case, publication rights 81 reserved for data providers is the major concern. In order to make both parties happy, policies for 82 prompt data sharing as common practice and emergency routine are to be established, accepted, and 83 monitored by the society, where detailed considerations and facts, such as criteria for intellectual 84 property reservation, priority for publication, and credit for data providers [6], all must be thoroughly 85 announced and debated in professional and public settings.
body_text.section: Data sharing demands a data ecosystem

body_text.text: Openness emphasizes that both data themselves and the corresponding metadata should be 87 released, publicized, and readily accessible in user-friendly databases. "Nothing great is ever 88 accomplished in isolation". Databases are not only responsible for data storage and processing, but 89 also provide free internet access to all digital data.

Last but not the least, the element of usefulness highlights the importance of data quality and 98 completeness [11] . Data sharing is not a goal in itself but rather an effort to make data widely utilized.

99 Accordingly, data to be shared must be reliable and complete, as biases/errors are characteristic of 100 those in poor-quality or defective. Moreover, data in their full spectrum are definitely preferred,

BIBREF0.title: including all useful digital assets that contain, but not limited to, metadata, unprocessed data, derived 102 datasets, analyzed results, source codes, protocols, flowcharts

BIBREF1.title: For data managers, deposition, integration, and translation are of essence

BIBREF2.title: In order to promote 109 activities of data sharing, to provide easy access to all shared data, and to achieve full benefits from 110 sharable data, databases must act as hub through providing a suite of web services for digital data 111 deposition, integration, and translation (DIT) that are foundational elements for data management 112 (Figure 1)

BIBREF6.title: Collectively, data sharing is vital for translating data to knowledge, particularly when everyone in the 155 world faces the same threat. To maximize benefits of data sharing for everyone

BIBREF7.title: Elements must establish logistics and standards for data sharing, provide guidance for all users that 157 include, but not limited to, scientific researchers, policy makers, funding agencies, and journal 158 publishers, and carry out all data-sharing activities. Some of the data and related infrastructures built 159 in the processes, aside from the immediate utilization, may form historic memoirs and monuments 160 for both heroes and victims of the event. Nevertheless, we need to embrace a data-sharing culture 161 under both ordinary and extraordinary situations [17]. With shared future, we call upon our 162 professional colleagues to hold our hands together and collaborate full-heartedly to build a better data 163 planet

FIGREF0.text: National Center for Bioinformation, Beijing 100101, China 7 2 National Genomics Data Center, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 8 Beijing 100101, China 9 3 CAS Key Laboratory of Genome Sciences and Information, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese 10 Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101, China 11 4 University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101for the new acquisition, scientific researchers always begin with a thorough synthesis of 32 the existing data, especially those that have been demonstrated authentic and timely. This fact has to 33 be particularly emphasized more than ever, as all aspects of our daily life and its measurable activities, 34 for better and worse, are being generated and recorded to be part of the collection -known as the 35 BIG DATA. 36 37 Sharing data is vital for a community of shared future 38 Sharing data begins with building a willful and dedicated community who consents a shared future 39 at a global scale. On the one hand, public emergencies, such as epidemics and pandemics caused by 40 many emerging infectious diseases, especially the two-in-a-row coronaviruses, severe acute 41 respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and SARS-CoV-2 [1], often necessitate data sharing 42 to aid expedited translation of big data into knowledge and procedures to improve human health. On 43 the other hand, we are now being, and increasingly so, armed and empowered by many data-44 generating engines and tools, including high-throughput sequencing technologies and high-45 performance computing platforms, as well as their collaborative products -large-scale genomic big 46 data that are generated at exponentially growing rates; most of the data are being continuously 47 produced, often supported by public funding [2,3]. Clearly, data sharing becomes pivotal for many 48 considerations and plans for action in public emergencies, since the outcomes from data-sharing are 49 of essence in yielding a complete picture of emergency situation, accelerating scientific research and 50 knowledge discovery, and promoting sensible and expeditious decision-making as well. 51 Unfortunately, existing practices surrounding data sharing are not effective in achieving 52 maximum interests from our investments. Data sharing is hindered or slowed down by a lack of clear 53 identification of supporting elements for its implementation. What constitutes 'the elements of data 54 sharing' is, however, largely undefined. Therefore, clarifying and defining data-sharing elements 55 would be of fundamental significance. Especially, when the world faces unprecedented global threats 56 and encounters public emergency situations (e.g., SARS-CoV-2 has spread around more than 200 57 countries/regions with 2,213,653 infected cases and 154,462 deaths as of 18 April 2020), we, as a 58 community of shared future, need to specify vital elements of data sharing and establish rapid, open, 59 and effective data release norms. 60 61

FIGREF1.text: data providers, promptness, openness, and usefulness are of essence 73 For data providers, there are three key elements-promptness, openness, and usefulness (POU) -74 that serve as foundation guidelines for data sharing, particularly under public emergencies and critical 75 situations

TABREF0.text: Currently, there have been several large global 90 centers [7] in life sciences dedicated to molecular data (such as DNA/protein sequences and structures) 91 collection and management, including the US National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) 92 [8], the European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI) [9], and the China National Center for 93 Bioinformation/National Genomics Data Center (CNCB/NGDC) [10]. These publicly-supported 94 centers accept data submissions globally and provide data-sharing services worldwide. It has to be 95 emphasized that in order to keep data always accessible and long-lived, databases should be funded 96 in a long-term and sustainable manner.
